titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author: Prepared by Manuscript Division Staff

Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Lawyer and publicist. Correspondence, memoranda, diaries, notebooks, printed articles, speeches, newspaper clippings, scrapbooks, and other printed material reflecting Pinchot's interests in civil liberties, labor problems, government, and politics.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

corpname.part: United States. National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers of Amos Pinchot, lawyer and publicist, were given to the Library of Congress by his wife, Ruth Pickering Pinchot, 1944-1953. Additional material was given by Mark Meyer in 1985.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of Amos Pinchot were housed and described in 1953. The finding aid was revised in 2005. The Family and General Correspondence series were reprocessed and the finding aid was revised in 2009 by Lena H. Wiley and Maria R. Farmer.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Some photographs have been transferred to the Library's Prints and Photographs Division where they are identified as part of these papers.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of Amos Pinchot is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Amos Pinchot are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Amos Pinchot Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: B.A., Yale University, New Haven, Conn.
Studied law, Columbia University, New York, N.Y.
Served in First New York Volunteer Cavalry in Puerto Rico during the Spanish-American War
Studied law, New York Law School, New York, N.Y.
Deputy assistant district attorney, New York County, N.Y.
Supported Theodore Roosevelt and the Progressive Party
Active in movement to keep United States out World War I

chronitemset.event: Trustee, New York Philharmonic Society, New York, N.Y.
Founder and member, executive committee, Civil Liberties Union

chronitem.event: Supported Franklin D. Roosevelt for president
Broke with policies of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the New Deal

chronitemset.event: Opposed United States entry into World War II
Member, executive committee, New York chapter of America First Committee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Amos Pinchot (1873-1944) span the years 1856-1945, with the bulk of the collection dating from 1909 to 1942. The collection chiefly reflects Pinchot's career as a lawyer and reformer and consists of six series: Family Correspondence , General Correspondence , Subject File , Speeches and Writings , Printed Matter , and Oversize .

Topics of importance in the papers include civil liberties, labor problems, the Sherman Antitrust Act, opposition to militarism and war, the League of Nations, the Progressive Party, oil scandals, government ownership of railroads, the National Industrial Recovery Act and New Deal legislation, reorganization of the Supreme Court, cooperative housing, America First Committee, and presidential campaigns from 1916 to 1940. Prominent correspondents include William Edgar Borah, Louise Bryant, James Rudolph Garfield, Harold L. Ickes, William Kent, John Adams Kingsbury, Fiorello H. La Guardia, John L. Lewis, Gifford Pinchot, Ezra Pound, John Reed (1887-1920), Franklin D. Roosevelt, Theodore Roosevelt (1858-1919), and Henry L. Stimson.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in six series:

scopecontent.p: Letters sent and received by Amos Pinchot and Pinchot family members.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by year and month.
Organized into a chronological file and special file. The chronological file is arranged by year and month. The special file is arranged alphabetically by name of person, organization, or topic.
